title: Program Analyst - Family Planning Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at UNFPA (Dar es Salaam, Dar es Salaam) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions:
I applied for this position in November, 2015 and in January, 2016 I was called for a written interview.
 We were seven (7) participants who were called for that interview, but were divided into two batches. The first three attended a morning section and the rest four of us were called late morning. 

Getting there, each was assigned a computer in a separate room. The supervisor assisted in setting the exam to each participant individually. And hence the exam was done using computers.

The written interview consisted of five (5) essay questions which had to be answered all of them. The interview time for all the five questions was one (1) hour. After an hour, time up was called and the supervisor came to collect the exam, printed the responses to have the hard copy.

A code was assigned to each person and names were not supposed to be written on the answering sheet.
Interview Questions: What is the situation of Family Planning/Reproductive health program in Tanzania?

title: IT Support Interview

In addition, the interview had a late start and took longer than expected as the details were not communicated to me before hand. Moreover, I was called late the afternoon before to advise me to come for an interview. Something which I found to be a bit annoying and signs of lack of proper organization. 

The actual interview process entailed a competency based interview, followed by a 25 minute test of my knowledge of concepts relating to expected area of work.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you were working on a project and the risks you faced and how you overcame those risks.

title: Several At the P4 and P5 Level Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 months. I interviewed at UNFPA (Bangkok) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: There is often a written test first (sometimes second) and then an interview via internet with a group of interviewers.  They ask you a set of questions to do with competencies (that are listed in the job description, but they usually list every competency in their list, so it is not that helpful in preparing) and want specific examples of what you have done and what the results were, what you would differently.  In my experience, they always ask questions about teams and strategic alliances.  There is a huge book of interview questions that you can find on line if you know it exists.  But I heard recently that they are revising it and changing the questions.  The book will give you an idea of the types of questions.  They have a tendency to ask about the same competencies in most interviews (i.e. teams) and sometimes ask why you want to work for them or want this job, and what specific skills you bring to the job.
Interview Questions: Can you give a different example of when you have taken a strategic approach to a particular challenge or problem? Another one was:  Give example of how you have developed a strategic alliance.  Was it successful or not?

title: Programmer Officer/Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UNFPA in Jul 2009
Interview Descriptions: Interviews at the UN are competency-based. Check out the competencies described in the advertisement and figure out one or two good experiences for each one. The bottom line is that you have to show that you know how to apply these competencies and that you have done that in your previous work. Interviews typically take 45 min to 1h. You may be called for a second interview, but this is rare. For higher level posts (P5 and above) you may have to go through some tests by a outside company (focusing on your skills, how would you react in this situation, etc). For a previous interview, I had to take a written test before the 1:1 interview, but again this is not so common and generally for posts that require specific skills (for example writing or editing).
Interview Questions: What are the steps you would take to prepare a strategy?

title: Project Secretary Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UNFPA (Male) in Apr 2009
Interview Descriptions: Interview was quite intense, although I think that was probably because I was kind of new to this kind of desk-based secretarial work. I believe it's how you present yourself, though, that makes the most impact. Your language skills matter a lot and your self confidence could take you a long way when it comes to impressing your potential employer.
Interview Questions: This was a project about HIV related awareness all over the country and I was asked my personal opinion on the issues surrounding it.
